Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Future Earth Interim Director and Implementation
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides support for the initial operations of Future Earth, an international research program that will provide the knowledge required for societies to face the challenges posed by Global Environmental Change (GEC) and to identify opportunities for transitions to global sustainability. Building on 30 years of international collaboration under the ICSU GEC programs, Future Earth aims to facilitate collaboration among natural and social science researchers and stakeholders from many countries. New research ideas and collaborations will emerge from this multidisciplinary framework. Future Earth will also help develop the next generation of globally engaged STEM researchers across many disciplines. This award will allow the interim leaders of Future Earth to begin implementation, continue regional engagement, support clustering of existing GEC projects so that they can make a full contribution to Future Earth, and create a small number of fast track initiatives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Future Earth issued a call in February 2014 for a set of Fast Track Initiatives (FTIs) and Cluster Activities (CAs), funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation and administered jointly by the International Council for Science (ICSU) and Future Earth Secretariat. FTIs create early opportunities to support Future Earth research with specific outputs related to a research or an engagement focus. Their goal is to either solve an issue swiftly, or to establish the basis for a longer-term research effort, which can seek funding elsewhere. The Cluster Activities allow existing global research projects to engage with Future Earth’s integrated and co-designed science agenda to create the opportunity to join together in either longer-term collaborations or mergers. This plays a role in reshaping the existing project structures, by supporting joint planning between existing projects, development of new organisational and research plans, and to identify and develop collaboration with potential stakeholders and partners, with the overall aim to enhance capability to meet Future Earth needs.

From this competition to form FTIs or CAs, the 10 following proposals were selected for funding:

1.       Exploring Nitrogen in Future Earth (FTI)

2.       Global Biodiversity Monitoring, Prediction and Reporting (CA)

3.       Liveable Urban Futures (FTI)

4.       Seeds of a Good Anthropocene (FTI)

5.       Scientific Support for IPBES Knowledge Generation (CA)

6.        Extreme Events and Environments from Climate to Society (E3S) (CA)

7.       Linking Earth System and Socio-economic models to predict and manage changes in land use and biodiversity (CA)

8.       Sustainability for Water, Food and Energy through Integrated Water Information and improved governance (CA)

9.        ArcticSTAR (CA)

10.   Towards an Integrated Africa Climate Research for Development Cluster Activity Proposal (CA)

As a whole, around 30 workshops and conferences were held under the FTIs/CAs banner. Participants to these workshops came from various countries in all continents and from a great diversity of disciplines and backgrounds within and beyond the Future Earth community. Stakeholders outside science were represented in many of these workshops or in events coupled with these workshops such as science-policy dialogues.

FTIs and CAs intensified their publication activities (articles in scientific journals and open access books) throughout the project life. Some of them have developed websites and blogs.

Most of the time, knowledge contributions of FTIs and CAs relate to methodologies, indicators, data and modeling, that can help advancing new research and/or support policy processes such as the Intergovernmental Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) and the Sustainable Development Goals.

Many FTIs and CAs have prepared the transition towards new initiatives through applying to new sources of funding including Belmont Forum calls (Transformations to Sustainability and the Sustainable Urbanisation Global Initiative). All FTIs and CAs have contributed to the development of the Future Earth Knowledge Action Networks (KAN). For instance, the Liveable Urban Futures FTI has been instrumental in the development of the Urban KAN. The Nexus Cluster has significantly contributed to the Nexus KAN. Finally, the E3S Cluster prepared an expression of interest for a Future Earth Knowledge Action Network on Extreme Events and Disaster Risk Reduction.
